message.content:
'/Users/seanreed/PythonProjects/seanreed1111.github.io' has a static site that is for hosting on github pages.
I want you to make a plan for setting up the same content on an entirely new site which I will just build and view locally. I want the new site to use modern best practices of nextjs and I want it in react and typescript.

content.thinking:
The user wants me to create a plan for migrating their existing static GitHub Pages site to a new Next.js site using React and TypeScript. They want this to be built locally.

First, I should:
1. Examine the existing GitHub Pages site to understand what content and structure it has
2. Create a plan for migrating to Next.js with React and TypeScript

This is clearly a planning task that requires:
- Understanding the existing site structure
- Deciding on the architecture for the new Next.js site
- Planning the migration approach

This is a good candidate for EnterPlanMode because:
- It's a non-trivial implementation task (building a new site)
- There are multiple valid approaches (different Next.js features, routing strategies, styling approaches)
- The user should approve the approach before I start implementing
- It will involve multiple files and architectural decisions

I should use the EnterPlanMode tool to transition into plan mode where I can explore the existing site and design the migration plan.

content.text: I'll help you create a plan for migrating your GitHub Pages site to a modern Next.js site with React and TypeScript. This is a significant architectural task, so let me enter plan mode to explore your existing site and design the migration approach.

content.content:

4. Use AskUserQuestion if you need to clarify the approach
5. Design a concrete implementation strategy
6. When ready, use ExitPlanMode to present your plan for approval

Remember: DO NOT write or edit any files yet. This is a read-only exploration and planning phase.

content.content:
1# Sean Reed - Portfolio Website
     2
     3A modern, responsive portfolio website showcasing my projects and skills. Built with HTML5, Tailwind CSS, and vanilla JavaScript, and hosted on GitHub Pages with automatic HTTPS.
     4
     5 **Live Site:** [https://seanreed1111.github.io](https://seanreed1111.github.io)
     6
     7## Features
     8
     9- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first approach that looks great on all devices
    10- **Modern UI**: Clean, professional design using Tailwind CSS
    11- **Smooth Animations**: Subtle fade-in effects and smooth scrolling
    12- **Accessible**: WCAG AA compliant with semantic HTML and ARIA labels
    13- **Fast Loading**: CDN-based Tailwind CSS for optimal performance
    14- **GitHub Pages Hosting**: Free hosting with automatic HTTPS
    15
    16## Sections
    17
    181. **Navigation**: Sticky header with mobile hamburger menu
    192. **Hero**: Eye-catching introduction with call-to-action buttons
    203. **About**: Professional summary and skills showcase
    214. **Projects**: Grid of project cards (currently placeholder projects)
    225. **Contact**: Multiple ways to get in touch
    236. **Footer**: Social links and copyright information
    24
    25## Technology Stack
    26
    27- **HTML5**: Semantic markup for structure
    28- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework via CDN
    29- **JavaScript**: Vanilla JS for interactivity
    30- **Font Awesome**: Icon library for visual elements
    31- **GitHub Pages**: Static site hosting with HTTPS
    32
    33## Project Structure
    34
    35```
    36seanreed1111.github.io/
    37 index.html              # Main portfolio page
    38 style.css               # Custom CSS styles
    39 script.js               # JavaScript for interactivity
    40 assets/                 # Images and resources
    41    project-placeholder.svg
    42 README.md              # This file
    43```
    44
    45## Local Development
    46
    47To view the site locally:
    48
    491. Clone the repository:
    50   ```bash
    51   git clone https://github.com/seanreed1111/seanreed1111.github.io.git
    52   cd seanreed1111.github.io
    53   ```
    54
    552. Open `index.html` in your browser:
    56   ```bash
    57   # On macOS
    58   open index.html
    59
    60   # On Linux
    61   xdg-open index.html
    62
    63   # On Windows
    64   start index.html
    65   ```
    66
    67   Or use a local development server:
    68   ```bash
    69   # Using Python 3
    70   python -m http.server 8000
    71
    72   # Using Node.js http-server
    73   npx http-server
    74   ```
    75
    763. View at `http://localhost:8000` (or the port your server uses)
    77
    78## Customization
    79

file.content:
# Sean Reed - Portfolio Website

A modern, responsive portfolio website showcasing my projects and skills. Built with HTML5, Tailwind CSS, and vanilla JavaScript, and hosted on GitHub Pages with automatic HTTPS.

 **Live Site:** [https://seanreed1111.github.io](https://seanreed1111.github.io)

## Features

- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first approach that looks great on all devices
- **Modern UI**: Clean, professional design using Tailwind CSS
- **Smooth Animations**: Subtle fade-in effects and smooth scrolling
- **Accessible**: WCAG AA compliant with semantic HTML and ARIA labels
- **Fast Loading**: CDN-based Tailwind CSS for optimal performance
- **GitHub Pages Hosting**: Free hosting with automatic HTTPS

## Sections

1. **Navigation**: Sticky header with mobile hamburger menu
2. **Hero**: Eye-catching introduction with call-to-action buttons
3. **About**: Professional summary and skills showcase
4. **Projects**: Grid of project cards (currently placeholder projects)
5. **Contact**: Multiple ways to get in touch
6. **Footer**: Social links and copyright information

## Technology Stack

- **HTML5**: Semantic markup for structure
- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework via CDN
- **JavaScript**: Vanilla JS for interactivity
- **Font Awesome**: Icon library for visual elements
- **GitHub Pages**: Static site hosting with HTTPS

## Project Structure

```
seanreed1111.github.io/
 index.html              # Main portfolio page
 style.css               # Custom CSS styles
 script.js               # JavaScript for interactivity
 assets/                 # Images and resources
    project-placeholder.svg
 README.md              # This file
```

## Local Development

To view the site locally:

1. Clone the repository:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/seanreed1111/seanreed1111.github.io.git
   cd seanreed1111.github.io
   ```

2. Open `index.html` in your browser:
   ```bash
   # On macOS
   open index.html

   # On Linux
   xdg-open index.html

   # On Windows
   start index.html
   ```

   Or use a local development server:
   ```bash
   # Using Python 3
   python -m http.server 8000

   # Using Node.js http-server
   npx http-server
   ```

3. View at `http://localhost:8000` (or the port your server uses)

## Customization

### Update Personal Information

1. **Email**: Replace `your.email@example.com` with your actual email in `index.html`
2. **LinkedIn**: Update the LinkedIn URL in the contact section and footer
3. **Skills**: Modify the skills badges in the About section
4. **Bio**: Update the description text in the About section

### Add Real Projects

When you're ready to replace the placeholder projects:

1. Add project screenshots to the `assets/` folder
2. Update project cards in the Projects section of `index.html`:
   - Replace project titles and descriptions
   - Update technology tags
   - Add links to live demos and GitHub repositories
   - Enable the demo/code buttons (remove `disabled` attribute and update classes)
   - Remove or update "Coming Soon" text

### Customize Colors

The site uses Tailwind's blue and indigo color palette by default. To customize:

1. **Using Tailwind Config**: Add a custom configuration in the `<head>` section:
   ```html
   <script>
     tailwind.config = {
       theme: {
         extend: {
           colors: {
             primary: '#your-color',
           }
         }
       }
     }
   </script>
   ```

2. **Or modify CSS**: Update colors in `style.css` for custom styling

## Deployment

This site is automatically deployed via GitHub Pages:

1. Push changes to the `main` branch
2. GitHub Actions will build and deploy automatically
3. Changes appear live within minutes at `https://seanreed1111.github.io`

### Initial Setup (if not already done)

1. Create a repository named `seanreed1111.github.io`
2. Push this code to the repository
3. Go to Settings  Pages
4. Set source to "Deploy from a branch"
5. Select `main` branch and `/ (root)` folder
6. Save and wait for deployment

## Browser Support

- Chrome/Edge (latest)
- Firefox (latest)
- Safari (latest)
- Mobile browsers (iOS Safari, Chrome Mobile)

## Performance

- Lighthouse scores: 90+ on Performance, Accessibility, Best Practices, SEO
- Fast load times via CDN resources
- Optimized images and minimal JavaScript

## Accessibility

- Semantic HTML5 elements
- ARIA labels for navigation
- Keyboard navigation support
- Sufficient color contrast (WCAG AA)
- Alt text for images
- Focus indicators

## Future Enhancements

- [ ] Add real project showcases with live demos
- [ ] Integrate blog section
- [ ] Add dark mode toggle
- [ ] Include resume/CV download
- [ ] Add contact form with backend service
- [ ] Implement analytics
- [ ] Add testimonials section
- [ ] Include animation library (AOS)

## License

This project is open source and available under the [MIT License](LICENSE).

## Contact

- **Email**: your.email@example.com
- **GitHub**: [@seanreed1111](https://github.com/seanreed1111)
- **LinkedIn**: [Your LinkedIn Profile](https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile)

---

Built with  using Tailwind CSS

file.content:
# Sean Reed - Portfolio Website

A modern, responsive portfolio website showcasing my projects and skills. Built with HTML5, Tailwind CSS, and vanilla JavaScript, and hosted on GitHub Pages with automatic HTTPS.

 **Live Site:** [https://seanreed1111.github.io](https://seanreed1111.github.io)

## Features

- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-first approach that looks great on all devices
- **Modern UI**: Clean, professional design using Tailwind CSS
- **Smooth Animations**: Subtle fade-in effects and smooth scrolling
- **Accessible**: WCAG AA compliant with semantic HTML and ARIA labels
- **Fast Loading**: CDN-based Tailwind CSS for optimal performance
- **GitHub Pages Hosting**: Free hosting with automatic HTTPS

## Sections

1. **Navigation**: Sticky header with mobile hamburger menu
2. **Hero**: Eye-catching introduction with call-to-action buttons
3. **About**: Professional summary and skills showcase
4. **Projects**: Grid of project cards (currently placeholder projects)
5. **Contact**: Multiple ways to get in touch
6. **Footer**: Social links and copyright information

## Technology Stack

- **HTML5**: Semantic markup for structure
- **Tailwind CSS**: Utility-first CSS framework via CDN
- **JavaScript**: Vanilla JS for interactivity
- **Font Awesome**: Icon library for visual elements
- **GitHub Pages**: Static site hosting with HTTPS

## Project Structure

```
seanreed1111.github.io/
 index.html              # Main portfolio page
 style.css               # Custom CSS styles
 script.js               # JavaScript for interactivity
 assets/                 # Images and resources
    project-placeholder.svg
 README.md              # This file
```

## Local Development

To view the site locally:

1. Clone the repository:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/seanreed1111/seanreed1111.github.io.git
   cd seanreed1111.github.io
   ```

2. Open `index.html` in your browser:
   ```bash
   # On macOS
   open index.html

   # On Linux
   xdg-open index.html

   # On Windows
   start index.html
   ```

   Or use a local development server:
   ```bash
   # Using Python 3
   python -m http.server 8000

   # Using Node.js http-server
   npx http-server
   ```

3. View at `http://localhost:8000` (or the port your server uses)

## Customization

### Update Personal Information

1. **Email**: Replace `your.email@example.com` with your actual email in `index.html`
2. **LinkedIn**: Update the LinkedIn URL in the contact section and footer
3. **Skills**: Modify the skills badges in the About section
4. **Bio**: Update the description text in the About section

### Add Real Projects

When you're ready to replace the placeholder projects:

1. Add project screenshots to the `assets/` folder
2. Update project cards in the Projects section of `index.html`:
   - Replace project titles and descriptions
   - Update technology tags
   - Add links to live demos and GitHub repositories
   - Enable the demo/code buttons (remove `disabled` attribute and update classes)
   - Remove or update "Coming Soon" text

### Customize Colors

The site uses Tailwind's blue and indigo color palette by default. To customize:

1. **Using Tailwind Config**: Add a custom configuration in the `<head>` section:
   ```html
   <script>
     tailwind.config = {
       theme: {
         extend: {
           colors: {
             primary: '#your-color',
           }
         }
       }
     }
   </script>
   ```

2. **Or modify CSS**: Update colors in `style.css` for custom styling

## Deployment

This site is automatically deployed via GitHub Pages:

1. Push changes to the `main` branch
2. GitHub Actions will build and deploy automatically
3. Changes appear live within minutes at `https://seanreed1111.github.io`

### Initial Setup (if not already done)

1. Create a repository named `seanreed1111.github.io`
2. Push this code to the repository
3. Go to Settings  Pages
4. Set source to "Deploy from a branch"
5. Select `main` branch and `/ (root)` folder
6. Save and wait for deployment

## Browser Support

- Chrome/Edge (latest)
- Firefox (latest)
- Safari (latest)
- Mobile browsers (iOS Safari, Chrome Mobile)

## Performance

- Lighthouse scores: 90+ on Performance, Accessibility, Best Practices, SEO
- Fast load times via CDN resources
- Optimized images and minimal JavaScript

## Accessibility

- Semantic HTML5 elements
- ARIA labels for navigation
- Keyboard navigation support
- Sufficient color contrast (WCAG AA)
- Alt text for images
- Focus indicators

## Future Enhancements

- [ ] Add real project showcases with live demos
- [ ] Integrate blog section
- [ ] Add dark mode toggle
- [ ] Include resume/CV download
- [ ] Add contact form with backend service
- [ ] Implement analytics
- [ ] Add testimonials section
- [ ] Include animation library (AOS)

## License

This project is open source and available under the [MIT License](LICENSE).

## Contact

- **Email**: your.email@example.com
- **GitHub**: [@seanreed1111](https://github.com/seanreed1111)
- **LinkedIn**: [Your LinkedIn Profile](https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile)

---

Built with  using Tailwind CSS

## Static Site Exploration Report

### 1. Directory Structure and File Organization

 script.js               # Vanilla JavaScript functionality
 assets/                 # Asset folder (minimal)
    project-placeholder.svg
 README.md               # Documentation
 .git/                   # Git repository
```

The project uses a single-page portfolio approach with no build process or dependencies management.

### 2. Pages and Content

**Single Page with 5 Main Sections:**

- **Navigation**: Fixed header with responsive mobile hamburger menu (sticky positioning)
- **Hero Section**: Large introduction banner with "Hi, I'm Sean Reed" headline, tagline, and two CTA buttons
- **About Section**: 
  - GitHub profile image
  - Bio text: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code."
  - 8 skill badges (Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker)
- **Projects Section**: Grid layout (3 columns on desktop) with 3 placeholder project cards:
  - E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL)
  - Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB)
  - Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask)

input.prompt:
Design a comprehensive implementation plan for migrating the static portfolio site to Next.js 15+ with React 19+ and TypeScript.

## Context from Exploration:

**Current Site Structure:**
- Single-page portfolio (index.html) with 5 sections: Navigation, Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer
- Tailwind CSS via CDN
- Vanilla JavaScript features: mobile menu toggle, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations (Intersection Observer)
- Font Awesome icons via CDN
- 1 SVG asset (project-placeholder.svg)
- 3 placeholder project cards (currently "Coming Soon")
- Responsive design (mobile-first, 768px breakpoint)
- No build process currently

**Key Features to Preserve:**
1. Mobile hamburger menu with toggle
2. Smooth scrolling navigation with offset
3. Active nav link highlighting based on scroll position
4. Fade-in animations on scroll (project cards)
5. Hover effects on cards
6. Accessibility features (ARIA, semantic HTML, keyboard nav)
7. 8 skill badges in About section
8. Contact cards (Email, GitHub, LinkedIn)

**Design Requirements:**
- Next.js 15+ with App Router
- React 19+ with TypeScript
- Modern best practices (2026)
- Built for local development and viewing
- Maintainable, scalable architecture
- Component-based design
- Type-safe implementation

## Plan Should Include:

1. **Project Structure:** Modern Next.js App Router structure with proper organization
2. **Component Architecture:** Break down into logical, reusable components
3. **TypeScript Types:** Define types for projects, skills, contacts, etc.
4. **Styling Approach:** Tailwind CSS setup (not CDN - proper Next.js integration)
5. **State Management:** Where needed (nav menu, scroll position)
6. **Animations:** React-based alternatives to vanilla JS (Intersection Observer with hooks)
7. **Data Structure:** How to organize content data (projects, skills, etc.)
8. **Routing:** Even though single-page, consider structure for future expansion
9. **Assets:** How to handle images and icons
10. **Configuration:** Essential Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind config

**Considerations:**
- Keep it simple - avoid over-engineering
- Use modern React patterns (hooks, not class components)
- Type safety throughout
- Easy to extend (add real projects, blog posts, etc.)
- Maintain performance (static generation preferred)
- Preserve all current functionality

Provide a detailed, step-by-step implementation plan with file structure and key decisions.

- Single-page portfolio (index.html) with 5 sections: Navigation, Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer

- 3 placeholder project cards (currently "Coming Soon")

7. 8 skill badges in About section

**Design Requirements:**
- Next.js 15+ with App Router
- React 19+ with TypeScript
- Modern best practices (2026)
- Built for local development and viewing
- Maintainable, scalable architecture
- Component-based design
- Type-safe implementation

input.content:
# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be built for local development and viewing.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`
4. Configure for static export (`output: 'export'` in next.config.ts)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, icon, proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, icon

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Font Awesome integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- Font Awesome via CDN initially
- Can migrate to react-icons later

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be built for local development and viewing.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`
4. Configure for static export (`output: 'export'` in next.config.ts)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, icon, proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, icon

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Font Awesome integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- Font Awesome via CDN initially
- Can migrate to react-icons later

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [x] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [x] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [x] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [x] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [x] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [x] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [x] Project cards show hover effects
- [x] Contact links work correctly
- [x] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [x] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [x] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [x] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be built for local development and viewing.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Content to Migrate
- **Name**: Sean Reed
- **Tagline**: "Software Developer passionate about building elegant solutions to complex problems"
- **Bio**: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code." + "Note: I do not look like this." (regarding GitHub avatar)
- **Skills**: Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/seanreed1111 (@seanreed1111)
- **Avatar**: https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5740286?v=4
- **Email**: your.email@example.com (placeholder - needs updating)
- **LinkedIn**: https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile (placeholder - needs updating)
- **Projects**:
  1. E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL)
  2. Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB)
  3. Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask)

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`
4. Configure for static export (`output: 'export'` in next.config.ts)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, icon, proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, icon

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Font Awesome integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- Font Awesome via CDN initially
- Can migrate to react-icons later

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [x] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [x] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [x] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [x] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [x] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [x] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [x] Project cards show hover effects
- [x] Contact links work correctly
- [x] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [x] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [x] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [x] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be built for local development and viewing.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Content to Migrate
- **Name**: Sean Reed
- **Tagline**: "Software Developer passionate about building elegant solutions to complex problems"
- **Bio**: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code." + "Note: I do not look like this." (regarding GitHub avatar)
- **Skills**: Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/seanreed1111 (@seanreed1111)
- **Avatar**: https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5740286?v=4
- **Email**: your.email@example.com (placeholder - needs updating)
- **LinkedIn**: https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile (placeholder - needs updating)
- **Projects**:
  1. E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL)
  2. Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB)
  3. Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask)

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`, `react-icons`
4. Configure for static export (`output: 'export'` in next.config.ts)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, IconComponent (React Icons), proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, IconComponent (React Icons)

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Verify React Icons integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- Font Awesome via CDN initially
- Can migrate to react-icons later

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [x] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [x] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [x] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [x] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [x] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [x] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [x] Project cards show hover effects
- [x] Contact links work correctly
- [x] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [x] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [x] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [x] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

**TypeScript:**

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly

content.text:
Great question! The plan I created configures it as a **static site** (using `output: 'export'` in Next.js config). Here's what that means:

**Static Export (Current Plan):**
- Pre-rendered to static HTML/CSS/JS files
- No Node.js server required
- View locally by running `pnpm build` then opening files
- Deploy anywhere (Netlify, Vercel, GitHub Pages, or just open index.html)
- Perfect for a portfolio site with no server-side features

**Dynamic Next.js (Alternative):**
- Requires Node.js server running (`pnpm dev` or `pnpm start`)
- Can use server features (API routes, server components, ISR)
- More flexible for future features (contact forms, etc.)
- Still very fast with React Server Components

Since you mentioned wanting to "build and view locally" and your current site is static, I defaulted to static export. However, **I can easily configure it either way** - just one line in the config file.

Which would you prefer?

1. **Static** (simpler, no server needed)
2. **Dynamic** (more features available, requires running dev server)

For a portfolio site, static is usually perfect unless you plan to add server-side features later.

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be built for local development and viewing.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Content to Migrate
- **Name**: Sean Reed
- **Tagline**: "Software Developer passionate about building elegant solutions to complex problems"
- **Bio**: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code." + "Note: I do not look like this." (regarding GitHub avatar)
- **Skills**: Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/seanreed1111 (@seanreed1111)
- **Avatar**: https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5740286?v=4
- **Email**: your.email@example.com ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **LinkedIn**: https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **Projects**:
  1. E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL) - "A full-featured e-commerce platform with product management, shopping cart, and secure payment integration."
  2. Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB) - "A collaborative task management application with real-time updates, drag-and-drop functionality, and team collaboration features."
  3. Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask) - "An interactive analytics dashboard for visualizing complex datasets with customizable charts, filters, and export capabilities."

**Note**: The email and LinkedIn URLs in the old site are placeholders. These will be migrated as-is and can be updated in the data files after implementation.

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`, `react-icons`
4. Configure for static export (`output: 'export'` in next.config.ts)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, IconComponent (React Icons), proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, IconComponent (React Icons)

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Verify React Icons integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- React Icons package (`react-icons`)
- Tree-shakeable, better bundle size
- Import specific icons as React components (e.g., `FaGithub`, `FaLinkedin`, `FaEnvelope` from `react-icons/fa`)
- Type-safe with TypeScript

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [x] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [x] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [x] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [x] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [x] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [x] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [x] Project cards show hover effects
- [x] Contact links work correctly
- [x] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [x] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [x] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [x] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be configured as a dynamic Next.js app for local development with the ability to add server-side features later.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Content to Migrate
- **Name**: Sean Reed
- **Tagline**: "Software Developer passionate about building elegant solutions to complex problems"
- **Bio**: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code." + "Note: I do not look like this." (regarding GitHub avatar)
- **Skills**: Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/seanreed1111 (@seanreed1111)
- **Avatar**: https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5740286?v=4
- **Email**: your.email@example.com ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **LinkedIn**: https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **Projects**:
  1. E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL) - "A full-featured e-commerce platform with product management, shopping cart, and secure payment integration."
  2. Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB) - "A collaborative task management application with real-time updates, drag-and-drop functionality, and team collaboration features."
  3. Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask) - "An interactive analytics dashboard for visualizing complex datasets with customizable charts, filters, and export capabilities."

**Note**: The email and LinkedIn URLs in the old site are placeholders. These will be migrated as-is and can be updated in the data files after implementation.

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`, `react-icons`
4. Configure Next.js for dynamic development (default config, no static export)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, IconComponent (React Icons), proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, IconComponent (React Icons)

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Verify React Icons integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Development testing
   - Production build
   - Responsive design verification

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Static export for local viewing
- Image optimization disabled (required for static export)
- Strict React mode enabled

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- React Icons package (`react-icons`)
- Tree-shakeable, better bundle size
- Import specific icons as React components (e.g., `FaGithub`, `FaLinkedin`, `FaEnvelope` from `react-icons/fa`)
- Type-safe with TypeScript

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [x] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [x] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [x] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [x] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [x] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [x] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [x] Project cards show hover effects
- [x] Contact links work correctly
- [x] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [x] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [x] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [x] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

# Next.js Portfolio Migration Plan

## Overview
Migrate the static GitHub Pages portfolio site to a modern Next.js 15+ application with React 19+, TypeScript, and Tailwind CSS. The site will be configured as a dynamic Next.js app for local development with the ability to add server-side features later.

## Current Site Analysis
- **Structure**: Single-page portfolio with 5 sections (Hero, About, Projects, Contact, Footer)
- **Tech**: HTML/CSS/JS, Tailwind CSS via CDN, Font Awesome icons, vanilla JavaScript
- **Content**: 3 placeholder projects, 8 skill badges, 3 contact methods
- **Features**: Mobile menu, smooth scrolling, active nav highlighting, fade-in animations

## Content to Migrate
- **Name**: Sean Reed
- **Tagline**: "Software Developer passionate about building elegant solutions to complex problems"
- **Bio**: "I write picture books for kids about science and technology-related themes. Sometimes I also write code." + "Note: I do not look like this." (regarding GitHub avatar)
- **Skills**: Python, JavaScript, React, Node.js, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Git, Docker
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/seanreed1111 (@seanreed1111)
- **Avatar**: https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5740286?v=4
- **Email**: your.email@example.com ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **LinkedIn**: https://linkedin.com/in/your-profile ( placeholder in old site - will be kept as-is)
- **Projects**:
  1. E-commerce Platform (React, Node.js, PostgreSQL) - "A full-featured e-commerce platform with product management, shopping cart, and secure payment integration."
  2. Task Management App (TypeScript, React, MongoDB) - "A collaborative task management application with real-time updates, drag-and-drop functionality, and team collaboration features."
  3. Data Visualization Dashboard (Python, D3.js, Flask) - "An interactive analytics dashboard for visualizing complex datasets with customizable charts, filters, and export capabilities."

**Note**: The email and LinkedIn URLs in the old site are placeholders. These will be migrated as-is and can be updated in the data files after implementation.

## Migration Strategy

### Project Setup
1. Initialize Next.js 15+ with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS
2. Pin Node.js (v22) and pnpm (v10) with Volta
3. Install dependencies: `clsx`, `tailwind-merge`, `react-icons`
4. Configure Next.js for dynamic development (default config, no static export)

### Architecture

**Project Structure:**
```
my-project-site/
 app/
    layout.tsx              # Root layout with metadata
    page.tsx                # Main portfolio page
    globals.css             # Tailwind + custom styles
 components/
    layout/                 # Navigation, MobileMenu, Footer
    sections/               # Hero, About, Projects, Contact
    ui/                     # Reusable components (Button, Cards, etc.)
 hooks/                      # Custom React hooks
    useScrollPosition.ts
    useActiveSection.ts
    useIntersectionObserver.ts
    useMobileMenu.ts
 types/                      # TypeScript definitions
 data/                       # Content (projects, skills, contacts)
 lib/                        # Utilities (cn, scrollToSection)
 public/images/              # Static assets
```

**Key Components:**
- **Navigation**: Sticky nav with scroll-based styling, active section highlighting
- **MobileMenu**: Slide-in menu with backdrop, keyboard support
- **HeroSection**: Landing with gradient background and CTAs
- **AboutSection**: Bio and skill badges with staggered fade-in
- **ProjectsSection**: Grid of project cards with hover effects
- **ContactSection**: Contact method cards with icons
- **Footer**: Social links and copyright

**TypeScript Types:**
- `Project`: id, title, description, technologies, imageUrl, status, URLs
- `Skill`: id, name, category, IconComponent (React Icons), proficiency
- `ContactMethod`: id, type, label, value, IconComponent (React Icons)

**Custom Hooks:**
- `useScrollPosition`: Track window scroll position
- `useActiveSection`: Determine which section is currently in view
- `useIntersectionObserver`: Generic hook for fade-in animations
- `useMobileMenu`: Manage mobile menu state and body scroll lock

**Styling:**
- Tailwind CSS (proper build integration, not CDN)
- Custom utility classes in globals.css
- `cn()` helper for conditional class merging
- Responsive design (mobile-first, md breakpoint at 768px)

**Animations:**
- Intersection Observer API for fade-in effects
- CSS transitions for hover states
- Smooth scroll with offset for fixed navigation
- Staggered delays for sequential animations

### Implementation Steps

1. **Initialize Project** (30 min)
   - Create Next.js app with TypeScript and Tailwind
   - Pin versions with Volta
   - Install additional dependencies
   - Configure Next.js, TypeScript, Tailwind

2. **Types & Data** (30 min)
   - Define TypeScript interfaces
   - Create data files with content
   - Set up utility functions and constants

3. **Custom Hooks** (45 min)
   - Build scroll tracking hooks
   - Implement intersection observer hook
   - Create mobile menu state management

4. **UI Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Button, AnimatedSection, SkillBadge
   - ProjectCard, ContactCard
   - Test styling and animations

5. **Section Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Hero, About, Projects, Contact sections
   - Integrate with data and UI components
   - Verify responsive design

6. **Layout Components** (1-2 hours)
   - Navigation with scroll effects
   - Mobile menu with transitions
   - Footer with social links

7. **Assembly** (30 min)
   - Root layout with metadata
   - Main page composition
   - Verify React Icons integration

8. **Assets & Polish** (30 min)
   - Move images to public/
   - Update personal information
   - Accessibility check

9. **Testing** (30 min)
   - Start development server (`pnpm dev`)
   - Test all features and responsive design
   - Production build test (`pnpm build && pnpm start`)

## Key Technical Decisions

**Next.js Configuration:**
- App Router (modern, future-proof)
- Dynamic site (can add API routes, server components, etc.)
- Image optimization enabled (Next.js Image component fully functional)
- Strict React mode enabled
- Development server for local viewing (`pnpm dev`)
- Production mode for deployment (`pnpm build && pnpm start`)

**TypeScript:**
- Full strict mode for type safety
- Comprehensive type definitions
- No `any` types

**State Management:**
- React hooks only (no external library)
- Local state with useState
- Custom hooks for shared logic

**Icons:**
- React Icons package (`react-icons`)
- Tree-shakeable, better bundle size
- Import specific icons as React components (e.g., `FaGithub`, `FaLinkedin`, `FaEnvelope` from `react-icons/fa`)
- Type-safe with TypeScript

**Performance:**
- Static generation (SSG)
- Tailwind purges unused CSS
- Intersection Observer for efficient animations
- Lazy loading for images below fold

## Future Extensibility

Easy to add later:
- Blog with MDX (`/app/blog/`)
- Dynamic project pages (`/app/projects/[slug]/`)
- CMS integration (Sanity, Contentful)
- API routes (contact form)
- Dark mode toggle
- Analytics

## Critical Files to Implement

1. **app/page.tsx** - Main page assembly
2. **components/layout/Navigation.tsx** - Complex navigation logic
3. **hooks/useIntersectionObserver.ts** - Core animation hook
4. **types/index.ts** - Type safety foundation
5. **lib/utils.ts** - Essential utilities (cn, scrollToSection)

## Verification

After implementation, verify:
- [ ] Development server runs (`pnpm dev`)
- [ ] Site accessible at http://localhost:3000
- [ ] All sections visible and styled correctly
- [ ] Mobile menu opens/closes smoothly
- [ ] Smooth scrolling works with offset
- [ ] Active nav highlighting updates on scroll
- [ ] Fade-in animations trigger on scroll
- [ ] Project cards show hover effects
- [ ] Contact links work correctly
- [ ] Images load and display properly
- [ ] Responsive design works (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [ ] Production build succeeds (`pnpm build`)
- [ ] Production server runs (`pnpm start`)
- [ ] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [ ] Accessibility (keyboard nav, ARIA labels)

## Success Criteria

- Modern Next.js site with TypeScript
- Preserves all features from static site
- Clean, maintainable component architecture
- Type-safe implementation
- Responsive and accessible
- Can be viewed locally without server
- Easy to extend with new features

Perfect! I've updated the plan to configure the site as a **dynamic Next.js application**. The key changes:

1. **No static export** - Uses Next.js's default dynamic configuration
2. **Image optimization enabled** - Full Next.js Image component support with automatic optimization
3. **Development workflow** - Run `pnpm dev` to view locally at http://localhost:3000
4. **Production ready** - Can deploy to Vercel, Netlify, or any Node.js hosting
5. **Extensible** - Easy to add API routes, server actions, database integration, contact forms, etc.

This gives you the best of both worlds: a working portfolio now, with the flexibility to add server-side features whenever you want.
